Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemoselective Tools for Exploration of Natural Product Chemical Space
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support of a CAREER award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program at the National Science Foundation, Professor Erin Carlson of Indiana University will lead a research program that will focus on the development and application of chemoselective methods for the exploration of natural product chemical space. Continued investigation of natural products is essential for the discovery of small molecules to probe biological processes, as therapeutic leads, and to identify new molecular architectures for synthetic and biosynthetic studies. Current isolation strategies facilitate enrichment based on a restricted set of mechanisms that are dependent upon physical properties such as solubility or size. Generation of a method that separates compounds by a unique and complementary mechanism, such as functional group composition, would represent a major advance in the field and is a major goal of the proposed research. Preliminary work in Professor Carlson's lab has resulted in the generation of a tagging strategy for the enrichment of alcohol-containing natural products and confirmed the ability of this method to facilitate detection of low abundance species. This award will enable pursuit of tagging strategies for additional functional group classes and application of these tools to the exploration of myriad natural products sources resulting in the discovery of new natural products and novel chemical scaffolds.

This CAREER award to Professor Carlson of Indiana University will result in a number of broader impacts. Of particular emphasis will be the utilization of natural products as a platform to ignite an interest in and appreciation for chemistry, especially in girls and young women. Girls often do not feel a connection with science - they lack an understanding of how it is useful or relevant to their lives and cannot relate to the people they perceive as being scientists. Interest in science needs to be generated and nurtured to encourage girls to continue with science education. The PI will develop an outreach program called Natural Products and Lighting the Fire of Curiosity to ignite an interest in science in local elementary and middle school aged girls. This program will introduce students to natural products, focusing on compounds produced by plants. The outreach materials generated will be broadly disseminated via the internet to enable teachers worldwide to utilize these resources. To date, this program has been shared with over 125 students and is now published as an official activity available to Girl Scout troops throughout southern Indiana. Natural products will also be used as inspiration for the development of laboratory curriculum at Indiana University that more closely resemble genuine research experiences. Inquiry-based modules will be devised and included in both introductory and advanced organic laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Natural products, molecules produced by many microbes and plants, are recognized as privileged scaffolds due to their propensity to interact with biological targets. Natural compounds and their derivatives are a crucial component of today’s pharmaceutical arsenal, essential tools to probe myriad biological systems, and provide novel molecular architectures for synthetic and biosynthetic studies. Although ~300,000 natural products are currently known, this group encompasses only a small percentage of the biologically-produced small molecule universe. Since the advent of the genomic era, numerous bacterial species have been sequenced, revealing that they possess many more biosynthetic gene clusters than there are known natural products. Thus, it is clear that the biosynthetic potential of even well-studied organisms has been massively underexplored; however, rapid assessment of their remaining natural product repertoire requires transformation of the way that compound production is triggered and the workflow for lead prioritization and structure elucidation.

A high rate of rediscovery has plagued natural product discovery. To identify novel molecules, we developed an integrated approach that combines bacterial growth perturbation, a suite of mass spectrometry techniques, and comparative data analysis (informatics). We have identified more than 40 molecules, including those produced by soil microbes when they come into contact with other soil-dwelling organisms. We have also tackled the challenge of isolating the active constituents of a biological extract. We pioneered the development of methods to isolate natural products based upon a distinct and orthogonal chemical property: functional group composition. We devised enrichment tags for alcohol- and carboxylic acid-containing natural products based on formation of siloxyl ether and siloxyl ester bonds, respectively. To demonstrate the utility of chemoselective enrichment, we used our carboxylic acid-targeting resin to enrich borrelidin, a compound with activity against the causative agent of Lyme disease. In just two steps, we obtained >2x the yield of this molecule as compared to traditional separation techniques alone. Most recently, we reported the generation of a pyridyl disulfide-functionalized tag for the rapid detection of sulfur-containing natural products, a difficult to isolate class of compounds. This research resulted in 15 peer-reviewed publications and 3 patents, with additional publications in preparation.

Broader Impacts. We are deeply committed to encouraging girls to pursue science through outreach activities. We have developed multiple public engagement activities centered around natural products that play myriad roles in our daily lives. We have published an activity based on anthocyanins and connected with >800 students. In the past three years, we have expanded our programing to cover natural product source materials (e.g., collection of microbes), activities to learn about both pathogenic and environmental microbes, and the use of nanoparticles in our society. We have partnered with Girls Inc. EUREKA!, a STEM-based approach to engaging 8th-12th grade girls in a cohort (150 students) over five years so that they can see themselves in college. More than 70% of the participants are minorities and ~30% are from low-income households. We have worked with this program since 2016 and this past summer we held four sessions with the EUREKA!® students on the UMN campus: 2 hour-long sessions with the 8th graders and 2 hour-long sessions with the 9th graders. Because we see the same students multiple times in a summer and for multiple years, we have the opportunity to develop a long-term curriculum that engages the girls progressively (i.e., new activities build from previous knowledge).

In the spring of 2015, I developed a new lab course in Chemical Biology for the undergraduate chemistry majors at the University of Minnesota, which provides them with a unique opportunity to experience the tools used in this field early in their careers. The course has been so popular that it is now offered every semester and has already been taken by nearly 350 students. I continue to develop new experiments for this course and anticipate sustained interest in this interdisciplinary laboratory curriculum.

Additional outcomes of this project include: i) forge new links between analytical and organic chemistry, informatics, biochemistry, and microbiology; ii) enhance education through a highly interdisciplinary approach making this project ideal for training at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels; and iii) enable the Principle Investigator to serve the scientific community as a visible educator and promoter of diversity in higher education.
